rsbNotes.title: Josh 13–21
rsbNotes.text: 13:1–21:45 The third major section of the book details the division of the land among the tribes. The significance of these chapters is made explicit in 21:43–45. The lists of boundaries and towns represent the objective content of the promises of God. Although many of the places are no longer known, and although their allotment here did not in all cases mean that the designated tribe actually occupied them (23:13), they nevertheless are an elaborate testimony to the faithfulness of the Lord.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 13:1
rsbNotes.text:
13:1 Joshua was old. The implication is that further conquest will not take place under him.

very much land. The Book of Joshua speaks of both the complete fulfillment of God’s promises (11:23; 21:45) and the incompleteness of the actual possession of the land (e.g., 13:1; 23:4–5). Compare the New Testament perspective of the completeness of what has been given in Christ, and the future expectation that still remains (e.g., Eph. 1:3, 14). While the Book of Joshua testifies to Israel’s experience of the Lord’s complete faithfulness, the promise remained, pointing to the future. See notes 1:4; 21:45; Gen. 13:15.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 13:3
rsbNotes.text: 13:3 counted as Canaanite. The Philistines were not strictly speaking Canaanites, but their territory was in Canaan and was included in God’s promise to Israel.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 13:4
rsbNotes.text: 13:4 Amorites. See note 2:10.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 13:6
rsbNotes.text:
13:6 allot the land. See 14:2; 15:1 note; 18:6; 19:51.

inheritance. See note 1:6.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 13:7
rsbNotes.text: 13:7 Manasseh. The older of Joseph’s two sons. See Gen. 48 and notes.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 13:8–33
rsbNotes.text: 13:8–33 As the summary of the conquest in ch. 12 began with the kings and their territory east of the Jordan (12:1–6; cf. 1:12–15), so the account of the distribution of the land begins with the allocation of this territory to the tribes of Reuben (vv. 15–23), Gad (vv. 24–28), and the half-tribe of Manasseh (vv. 29–31) in the days of Moses. In this way what Joshua does is seen as the completion of what Moses began, and the unity of all Israel is affirmed, despite the geographical boundary of the Jordan (22:25) and the lapse of time between the work of Moses and Joshua. See ch. 22.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 13:8
rsbNotes.text:
13:8 Reubenites. Reuben was Jacob’s oldest son, born to Leah (Gen. 29:32; 35:22; 49:3, 4 and notes).

Gadites. Gad was Jacob’s seventh son, his first from Zilpah (Gen. 30:9–11; 49:19 and note).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 13:13
rsbNotes.text:
13:13 did not drive out. The significance of this failure of the Israelites will become clearer in the Book of Judges (Judg. 1:27–36; 2:20–3:6).

to this day. See note 4:9.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 13:14
rsbNotes.text: 13:14 the tribe of Levi. Levi was Jacob’s third son, born to Leah (Gen. 29:34; 34:25; 49:5 and notes). That Levi received no allotment of land from either Moses or Joshua is explained here and in v. 33 (also 14:3, 4; 18:7). See Deut. 18:1–8. The twelve tribes of Israel are counted in various ways in the Old Testament. For the division into twelve territories the descendants of Joseph are counted as two tribes, Ephraim and Manasseh (14:4; Gen. 48:5).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 13:22
rsbNotes.text:
13:22 Balaam . . . the son of Beor. See Num. 31:8. Balaam was associated with “the incident of Peor” (Num. 31:16) referred to in Josh. 22:17. Balaam’s evil influence was long remembered (2 Pet. 2:15; Rev. 2:14).

practiced divination. A soothsayer tries to attain knowledge by magical or occult means. This was a common practice among the pagans, but forbidden in Israel (Lev. 19:26; Deut. 18:9–14; 1 Sam. 15:23; 2 Kin. 17:17; 21:6; Is. 2:6; Ezek. 13:23).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 13:33
rsbNotes.text: 13:33 the tribe of Levi. See note on v. 14.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 14:1–5
rsbNotes.text: 14:1–5 This introduces the territories west of the Jordan and relates them to those on the east, explaining again the exception of the Levites. The effect is to keep the reader’s attention on the essential unity of all Israel. See note 13:8–33.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 14:1
rsbNotes.text:
14:1 inherit. See note 1:6.

Canaan. Here this means the land west of the Jordan.

Eleazar the priest. Eleazar was the son of Aaron the high priest (Ex. 6:23). He is mentioned before Joshua, possibly because of the priest’s role in casting lots (Ex. 28:30; 1 Sam. 2:28).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 14:2
rsbNotes.text: 14:2 by lot. See note 15:1.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 14:3–4
rsbNotes.text: 14:3, 4 the Levites . . . Manasseh and Ephraim. See note 13:14.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 14:6–15
rsbNotes.text: 14:6–15 The story of Caleb’s inheritance opens the account of the allotment of land under Joshua, while Joshua’s inheritance comes at the end (19:49–50). This framework illustrates the principles of human faithfulness to God met by God’s faithfulness to His promises. The story of Caleb is concluded in 15:13–19.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 14:6
rsbNotes.text:
14:6 Gilgal. This is probably the same Gilgal as in 10:43, to the east of Jericho.

Caleb. He represented Judah among the twelve spies sent by Moses from Kadesh-barnea into the land (Num. 13:6). Joshua represented Ephraim on the same mission (Num. 13:8) and they were the only two on that occasion to believe the promise of God (Num. 13:30; 14:6–9, 24, 30, 38; Deut. 1:36).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 14:7
rsbNotes.text: 14:7 as it was in my heart. Caleb’s report had expressed his trust in God’s promise. See Num. 14:6–9.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 14:8
rsbNotes.text: 14:8 I wholly followed the Lord. Caleb’s faith is exemplary.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 14:9
rsbNotes.text: 14:9 Moses swore. This oath is not recorded in Num. 14 or Deut. 1.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 14:12
rsbNotes.text:
14:12 Anakim. See note 11:21, 22.

I shall drive them out. Faith in God’s promise is not expressed in human passivity, but in active obedience. See notes 1:6, 7; 17:15.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 14:14
rsbNotes.text: 14:14 to this day. See note 4:9.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 14:15
rsbNotes.text: 14:15 the land had rest from war. See note 11:23.
